statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Hawaii 76, Creighton 60
article.story: HONOLULU (AP) -- Nearly every time Hawaii's Matt Lojeski shot from 3-point range, it found the bottom of the net. Lojeski scored a career-high 33 points, including 15 from 3-pointers, to lead Hawaii to a 76-60 victory over Creighton in the championship game of the Rainbow Classic on Saturday. Three of Lojeski's long-range shots came during a crucial run where the Rainbow Warriors (8-4) outscored the Bluejays 14-1 and regained the lead. Lojeski made 5-of-6 from behind the 3-point line. "It was just my night. Everything was dropping," said Lojeski, who was named the tournament's most valuable player. "It was unreal." He sunk 12-of-15 from the field, and he made all four of his free throw attempts. Nate Funk scored 25 for the Bluejays (6-4), who briefly took the lead by putting up eight straight points at the start of the second half. But they gave it up amid Lojeski's shooting barrage. Rainbow Warriors coach Riley Wallace said Lojeski's shooting should be remembered as a history-making event for Hawaii. "That's got to be one of the big all-time performances by a Hawaii guy, to come out and shoot like that," Wallace said. "He was in a zone." Wallace gave Lojeski opportunities to come out of the game, but Lojeski refused. "I kept asking him, 'Do you need a rest, do you need a rest?' And he said, 'No, no," Wallace said. With the win, Hawaii gained its 11th tournament title and has appeared in the championship game seven of the last eight seasons. Ahmet Gueye recorded 19 points for Hawaii. Overall, the Rainbow Warriors were highly accurate by making 60 percent of their 3-point attempts. Guard Matt Gibson, who scored four points with five assists, said Hawaii had to adjust to the slower pace of Creighton's ball-control strategy. But it helped that he could simply feed the ball to Lojeski much of the time, he said. "They didn't do too much gambling. Once we got a feel for it, we turned it around pretty good," Gibson said. "It's going to be a merry Christmas." The Bluejays' Dane Watts scored 12 points and Anthony Tolliver had 11. Hawaii held a 31-30 lead at the half in a back-and-forth struggle with four lead changes. But once the Rainbow Warriors lost and retook the lead with 14:17 left, they never relinquished it again. Hawaii beat San Francisco and Nebraska on its way to the championship game. Earlier Sunday, Nebraska defeated Houston 70-57 in the third-place game of the 43rd annual Rainbow Classic. Wyoming, Charlotte and Valparaiso also participated in the tournament.
